div.l: But fair and wel / she crepte in to the clerk
And lieth ful stille / and wolde haue take a slep
Withinne a while / this Iohn clerk vp lep
And on this goodwif / he leyde on sore
So mery a fit / ne hadde she ful yore
He prekith harde / and deep as he wer͗e wo wo mad
This Ioly lyf / han thes too clerkes lad
Til that the thridde cok / bi gan to synge
Alayn wax wery / in the dawenynge
For he hadde swonkyn / al the longe nyht
He saide farwel malyn / swete wiht
The day is com̄ / I may no lengere a bide
But euyr mo / wher so I go or ryde
I is thyn owne clerk / so have I seel
Now deere lemman / qduod she she go farewel
But or thou go / oo thing I wol the telle
Whan that thow / wendist homward bi the weye
Riht at thentre / of the dore bi hynde
Thow shalt a cake of half a busshel fynde
That was I maked / of thyn owne mele
Which that I halp my fadir for to stele
And goode lemman̄ / god save the and keepe
And with that word / almost she gan to weepe
Alayn vprist / and thouht / or that it dawe
I wol go crepyn in / bi my felawe
And fond the cradil / with his hand anoon
Bi god thouht he al wrong / I haue mys goon
My hed is doty / of my swynk to nyht
That maketh me / that I go nat a riht
I wot weel bi the cradell / I haue mys ga
Heere liht the miller / and his wyf Alswa
And forth he goth / a twenti deuyl way
Vn to the bedde / ther as the millere lay
He wende haue cropyn / bi his felawe Iohn
And bi the miller / he crepte in a noon
And cauht hym bi the necke ⁊and gan hym shake
He seyde Iohn / thou swynes hede a wake
